Award.AwardTitle: Next-generation instrumented buoys for the University of Wisconsin Trout Lake Station
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Wisconsin-Madison is awarded a grant that will allow its Trout Lake Station to purchase and deploy four fully-instrumented buoys (plus one spare) and associated telecommunication and data management equipment. The system is designed to allow year-round collection of high-frequency limnological data from four long-term study lakes. The data will be made publically available in near-real time. The Trout Lake Station is a year-round field station operated by the Center for Limnology at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Located in the Northern Highland Lake District in northern Wisconsin, the Station has a long history of research on the region's aquatic resources dating back to the 1920s.

The instrumented buoys will make high-frequency measurements of weather (air temperature, relative humidity, atmospheric pressure, wind speed and direction, and precipitation), water temperature throughout the water column, and near-surface dissolved oxygen, chlorophyll a, phycocyanin, and colored dissolved organic matter. During the open water season the data will be telemetered to the Station in near real time, run through an automated range check and posted to a publically available database. The four lakes to be instrumented differ in their size, depth, trophic status, color, water chemistry, hydrology, and biotic communities. All are long-term study lakes of the North Temperate Lakes Long-Term Ecological Research program and have more than 30 years of comprehensive limnological data available. The lakes are within 10km of each other (and the Trout Lake Station), so data from the buoys will be used to compare differential responses of lakes to nearly identical weather conditions. Such comparisons are powerful in predicting climatic responses of lakes in general. The buoy data will be used by a myriad of researchers who require background environmental data for their research projects on the study lakes. In addition, the data will be used widely within the Global Lakes Ecological Observatory Network in comparative studies of lake processes worldwide.

The instrumented buoys resulting from this award will help create new knowledge that has societal relevance, provide research opportunities and training for students, and increase the scientific literacy and interest of the general public. The buoy data will be used to address the likely effect of climate change and variation on lakes and to provide environmental context for population-, community-, and ecosystem-level studies. Two summer research experiences for undergraduates will be provided by this award. Finally, the buoy data in public engagement activities including an annual Trout Lake Station open house and a very popular and well-attended Science on Tap-Minocqua series held at the local community microbrewery. For more information about Trout Lake Station visit the website at http://limnology.wisc.edu/Trout_Lake_Station.php.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to develop and construct water quality sensing platforms (hereafter buoys) deployed in four lakes that differ in their size, depth, trophic status, color, water chemistry, hydrology, and biotic communities. These sensing platforms measure a variety of meteorological data such as wind speed and direction, air temperature, and precipitation as well is water quality variables such as dissolved oxygen and carbon dioxide and water temperature of the lake from the surface all the way to the bottom of the lake at one minute intervals. The buoys that we developed are a modular design with a surface platform that is attached in the summer which contains the meteorological sensors, data loggers, and cellular modems to relay the data in near real time. Prior to the lakes freezing over, the surface platform is removed and the water quality sensors with internal data loggers are subsurfaced below the water approximately 3 feet to collect data throughout the winter while the lakes are ice-covered. Data from the buoys will allow researchers to compare how the lake’s physical and biological dynamics vary and the important factors influencing those dynamics as well as the ecological dynamics of these lakes during ice-covered time periods when researchers historically do not collect data.

The grant provided training and professional development opportunities for four research scientists and techniciations in the area of buoy design, fabrication, deployment, and operation. Additional, these individuals gain extensive experience working with a variety of advanced sensors, data loggers, and the large datasets these sensors produce. Four undergraduate students were supported to work on all aspects of the project and gained experience in all areas identified above as well as analysis of large datasets. Several of these students also gained additional professional development training through a variety of workshops taught at the Trout Lake Research Station. One student is pursuing a professional career in engineering and another student was inspired by her work with this project to pursue graduate training with a research emphasis on using high frequency data from buoys to understand drivers of water quality issues such as toxic algae blooms.

The data generated from these buoys resulted in the first multi-year, multi-lake comparison of water column temperatures and lake productivity between open-water and ice-covered time periods at the 2018 Association for the Sciences of Limnology and Oceanography Summer Meeting (Lottig et al. 2018). Unexpectedly, we found very little difference in lake productivity estimates between open-water and ice-covered time periods in oligotrophic lakes. On the other hand, dystrophic bog lakes go anoxic extremely quickly once ice forms and we were able to document significant differences in lake productivity between open-water and ice-covered seasons. We also saw evidence of enhanced metabolic activity in the high dissolved organic carbon bog lakes right at ice out and hypothesize that this sudden spike in biological activity might be related to processing of labile carbon that built up under anoxic conditions over the ice-covered season.

The final pattern emerging from analyses of the initial data collected from the new buoy deployments relates to the thermodynamics of lakes during ice out. We saw evidence in a single lake of summer stratification patterns setting up under the ice prior to ice-out. Water temperatures under the ice approached 7 degrees celsius. Ice out is often thought to be the key event that sets up summer patterns and the open water season. However, these results indicate that ice-out may not be the best indicator and could be a potential explanation as to why fish spawning, which is triggered by water temperatures, sometimes occurs under the ice.

The development of the next generation instrumented sensing platforms at Trout Lake Station, especially the under-ice component, has led to an NSF proposal currently under consideration and an additional proposal that will be submitted shortly to an internal University of Wisconsin Madison competition to understand the ecological processes at stake with the loss of lake ice due to climate change. The under-ice sensing platforms have significantly increased our capacity to address key questions associated with this knowledge gap and thus are being leveraged by researchers in grant submissions and active research projects. There is a new faculty member and PhD student at the University of Wisconsin Madison Center for Limnology whose research will focus under-ice productivity and will rely extensively on the data generated by these sensing platforms. The data is already being used widely within the Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network (GLEON) in comparative studies of lake processes worldwide and we expect that the data will also be used by myriad researchers who require background environmental data for their research projects on the study lakes. Finally, the buoy designs, especially, the under-ice component, have been shared with researchers from other institutions who are seeking funding to support research leverage these platforms
